summary:
Poland-Lithuania was a powerful country in Europe from 1569 to 1795. It was formed when the Kingdom of Poland and the Grand Duchy of Lithuania joined together. At its biggest, it covered almost 400,000 square miles and had 12 million people.

The two countries had been close since 1385, and their union created a strong, large nation. It had its own parliament and elected kings. This was called the "Golden Liberty." The Commonwealth was known for its religious freedom and many different cultures.

However, over time, Poland-Lithuania became weaker and was divided up by neighboring countries. Before it ended, it made a new set of rules called the 3 May Constitution.
